so the
unit of information in roslyn is the syntax tree
and this is an abstract representation of your code
so we have a syntax tree a document if it is a compilable document we'll be
able to give you a syntax tree and that syntax tree
contains syntax nodes and it's essentially just like a dom
for your code so you have a root node and then that has child nodes and each
of those nodes have child nodes and some of these nodes will be things like a
declaration of a class or a declaration of a property and some of these nodes will be an opening brace
or a semicolon it goes right down to that sort of level
and then we have tokens within that so a token is something like an identifier
so a node might say i am a property declaration syntax and within that node
there is a token which is the identifier which is the name of the property
or it could be a semicolon then we have syntax trivia
because we also have white space and we have
commas in lists of attributes and we have comments and documentation comments
anything that the compiler doesn't actually compile into intermediate language is called trivia
and if you don't put trivia in then all your code will be generated as one great big long string and it'll be
completely unreadable like cobalt
there's a brilliant thing built into visual studio has he got the thing installed into visual studio he asks
himself we go to view here and we go to other windows

install for you is this syntax visualizer and then you can click on bits of your code
in your editor window here and it will jump to that bit of code
over in the syntax tree and so you can see here
if we go up to the top we've got a using directive there and that using directive consists of the
using keyword and then it's got some white space after
it for just that single space there and then it has an identifier name which is an
identifier token which is system and then it has the semicolon token
and end of line trivia or new line trivia okay and so you can go bouncing around
